conclusion: Empiricism forces the external world to appear as nothing more than a collection of mutually disconnected, ex nihilo events, since all there is to it is what observation reveals

There are social incentives to endorse official morality and disincentives to endorse actual morality
Institutional truth and morality are obvious and unambiguous; authentic counterparts are subtle and equivocal

The sociopath doesn't really believe or disbelieve anything
Sociopaths must believe that truth is malleable, that facts conform to wishes
Sociopaths must believe truth, morality, and merit are "relative" and a "matter of opinion"

For the sociopath, there is no distinction between thought and rationalization

Sociopathization is immediately preceded by a brief but intense period of psychosis
This psychosis is preceded by years of pretending things were fine when they weren't
Sociopathy is never reversible; it is systemic psychosis, not system-internal psychosis
So far as the sociopath seems to be getting better, it's because he is getting worse
There is nothing one loses upon sociopathizing that one will ever regain except in degraded form

The rationalizations mediating sociopathization can be identical with the writer's work-product
Compositions cannot undermine one another; the composer qua composer cannot step on anyone's toes

Unlike sociopaths and psychopaths, criminals can and do have meaningful object-relations with others

The criminal can have meaningful object-relations; the psychopath cannot
The criminal must suspend his object-relations to ply his trade; the psychopath has none to suspend
The ability to have meaningful connection presupposes ability to have values
If the criminal can connect meaningfully with even one person, he has values and is thus an agent
Evil must be distinguished from hate; everyone hates someone, but not everyone is evil
Evil is generalized, rigidified hate
Your hatred is person-specific (Jerry); Stalin's targeted humanity itself
Wickedness and criminality are not mutually exclusive; a given agent can be both
The "anti-social" group actually consists of five distinct groups: psychopaths, sociopaths, criminals, evil people, and haters
There is no way to understand repression or rationalization in strictly empiricist terms
The hypothesis of unconscious mental activity is the ultimate deviation from empiricism's strictures
There is no way to explain conscious mental activity except on the assumption of unconscious mental activity

To the extent a scientist complies with the empiricist credo that one must "stick to the facts," he cannot embed observable events in otherwise unobservable continuities
The empiricist, forced to hold that events occur spontaneously, is ipso facto incapable of explaining them

Empiricism is inimical to the idea of any invisible structure

Empiricism-based or empiricism-inspired methodologies have damaged psychology

Mach's characteristically empiricist position that molecules are but useful fictions was proven wrong by Einstein's work on Brownian motion
Propositions are non-spatiotemporal entities
Properties are non-spatiotemporal

Propositions consist of properties

The relata of logical relations must be things that are true or false
Properties cannot be identified with spatiotemporal entities whose constituents are that property's instances (scattered objects)

Empiricists deny that propositions exist because propositions, if they exist, are non-spatiotemporal
A proposition is what one affirms when one makes a statement; it is not identical with any sentence

Propositions consist of concepts
The meaning of a complex expression cannot be directly determined by convention; one must always figure out what is meant

It is only in a doubly derivative sense that one expression entails another
Statements to the effect that a sentence is "formally true" or an argument is "formally valid" are abbreviated ways of making statements about propositions
Empiricists attempt to spatiotemporalize meaning, and these attempts fail as badly as their attempts to spatiotemporalize properties
Wittgenstein's thesis that "meaning is use" cannot be correct, as it would imply linguistic activity could occur on planets with no sentient life

Although symbol-manipulations facilitate ratiocinative operations, anything that one can think with the help of symbols one can think without them

Different expressions are associated with different kinds of phenomenology
Congenial phenomenology alerts us to the presence of positive properties (truthfulness, validity) in expression-image series
Pleasant affects alert us to structural features in works of music, paintings, or buildings; unpleasant affects alert us to their absence
Empiricists are forced to espouse radically implausible views concerning affect and emotion because they mistakenly treat relations as properties
Colors, tastes, and fragrances are not "purely" subjective as empiricists claim
Colors are properties of three-place relations, not two-place relations between observer and object

A psychopath is someone who doesn't have a conscience and never had one to begin with
A sociopath is someone who had a conscience but ceased to have one
Sociopathogenesis is identical with, or largely constitutive of, a certain sort of rationalization
Sociopaths are people who "sell out" and "die inside," becoming empty husks that are but caricatures of their former selves
Psychopathy is a kind of perpetual infantilism

A given instance of some kind of metal won't have a certain coefficient of expansion unless all other such instances have the same coefficient—and the same holds for biological traits
Empiricism is systemically incapable of saying anything about how linguistic and cognitive competence affect character-architecture

The sensibility embodied in empiricism is inimical to the creation and cultivation of viable psychological theories
For epistemologists, empiricism is a doctrine; for others, it's a mentality that damages research even when researchers don't know what empiricism formally entails

It is often a conceptual, non-empirical question how to characterize a given body of data in a strictly empirical fashion

If properties don't exist, no argument involving properties is valid—but arguments are composed of propositions, and propositions consist of properties
Properties cannot be identified with scattered objects or any spatiotemporal entities

Quine's argument that there is no non-circular definition of "analytic" fails because it only considers trivial analytic truths

It isn't a matter of convention whether the conventions we adopt are consistent with one another
It isn't a matter of convention what follows from the conventions we adopt

No intension is identical with the corresponding extension; no property is identical with the corresponding set

x falls into a set S if, and only if, x is an instance of an instance of the property that constitutes S

Before a variable is assigned a referent, expressions containing it are neither confirmable nor tautologous

Chomsky's position that there is subpersonal mentation is not merely a reasonable hypothesis but de rigueur relative to obvious facts

Science is not about "sticking to the facts"—it is about organizing facts and positing hidden structures to restore continuities that observation strips away

Subpersonal awarenesses are expressed at the personal level in the form of phenomenological episodes

While AI models can write about emotions or self-awareness, they don't need to monitor their own operational state or adjust their processing in real-time
Unlike a human driver who maintains unified conscious awareness of an entire situation, autonomous vehicles handle each aspect separately through distinct processing modules

Self-driving cars process sequentially: receive image data, process images, classify objects, calculate responses, execute commands—still a series of distinct steps rather than continuous integrated process
Autonomous vehicles don't maintain a unified awareness of their situation and internal state
An autonomous combat robot that genuinely needs to preserve itself in a dynamic, threatening environment would need fundamentally different processing than current AI
A conscious-like system would need to integrate multiple inputs into unified awareness that immediately influences behavior
Like a martial artist adjusting their fighting style to an injury, an advanced robot would need to immediately develop new strategies based on compromised capabilities
Implementing consciousness-like features would require moving from sequential processing to continuous parallel awareness
Consciousness-like AI would require creating a unified workspace where multiple data streams are simultaneously accessible
Consciousness-like AI would require developing systems for real-time self-monitoring and adjustment
Consciousness-like AI would require enabling flexible, dynamic integration of different subsystems and implementing immediate feedback loops between perception and action
Consciousness-like features in AI would serve the same survival-promoting functions that consciousness serves in biological organisms
While autonomous vehicles process environmental data continuously, they do so through separate parallel processes rather than in a unified workspace
A collision isn't bad for an autonomous vehicle in any meaningful way—it simply triggers pre-programmed response routines; the system doesn't need to care about its continued existence
Modern factory cobots track human movements, monitor joint positions, and adjust movements, but these are separate subroutines rather than integrated awareness
Even sophisticated disaster response robots operate through separate processing modules rather than maintaining unified conscious-like workspace

Current AI systems lack true consciousness-like features because they process information in separate modules, respond to pre-programmed conditions rather than genuine self-preservation awareness, cannot flexibly integrate capabilities in novel ways, and lack real-time self-monitoring
Implementing consciousness-like features requires fundamentally different architectures that enable unified, real-time, self-preserving awareness—not just faster versions of current systems

If we didn't feel pain, we might leave our hand on a hot stove until severe tissue damage occurred; without immediate conscious experience of pain, we would need slow deliberate monitoring—inefficient and dangerous

Without conscious emotions, decision-making would be severely impaired; fear creates immediate action tendencies while triggering heightened awareness—far too fast for rational probability computation
Current AI processes text about emotions by identifying patterns and generating responses based on learned correlations, but without any functional analogue to emotional experience

Pain analogues in AI would include unified damage-registration that immediately interrupts all processes, priority flags making damage data accessible to all subsystems, and signals triggering rapid behavior modification without complex computation

Emotion analogues in AI would include fear systems creating immediate action tendencies when threat patterns detected, pleasure systems reinforcing beneficial behaviors, and anxiety systems increasing monitoring of potential threats
The DN model of explanation argues that scientific explanations consist in showing how events follow logically from natural laws and initial conditions
The DN model fails to capture how we actually explain most phenomena; AI systems engage in explanation through pattern recognition and local disruptions rather than DN-style reasoning
Deep learning models successfully predict and interpret phenomena without employing anything resembling DN-style reasoning
Even in physics, where the DN model seems most applicable, both human and artificial learning begin with pattern recognition rather than formal laws
Scientific explanation emerges from pattern recognition and causal understanding rather than being grounded in logical deduction from universal laws
We can readily identify causes without knowing complete psychological profiles or any universal laws about human responses
We can confidently identify causes without knowing exact conditions or precise laws—the DN model's requirement for complete laws is unrealistic
The DN model faces a serious epistemological challenge: the only way to select relevant antecedent conditions is to already have understanding of what causes the type of event we're trying to explain
A more realistic model of explanation focuses on identifying local disruptions to normal states, counter-disruptions that restore equilibrium, and proportionality between actions and reactions

When an AI system encounters a scenario, it doesn't employ DN explanation; it recognizes patterns from similar situations, identifies disruptions and responses, and makes predictions based on learned associations
Neural networks learn by minimizing loss functions—effectively reducing prediction errors—which parallels the anomaly minimization principle
Large language models make predictions based not on certainty but on minimizing discontinuity with context; they select tokens that create the least disruption to established context
Inflation is not possible in a barter economy since inflation is when money is overvalued and there is no money in a barter economy
AI systems organize information in embedding spaces where concepts whose association would generate fewer anomalies are positioned closer together
Modern transformers use attention mechanisms to weigh different parts of context in ways that minimize overall anomalies in predictions
The alignment between AI architecture and anomaly minimization suggests this principle captures something fundamental about how intelligence processes and validates information
Studying how AI systems learn and form beliefs offers valuable insights into the nature of knowledge itself

Rather than adopting multi-valued logic to handle cases where binary truth values seem inadequate, AI success points toward representing apparent vagueness through continuous properties while maintaining binary truth values
AI systems represent concepts not as binary predicates but as points in high-dimensional vector spaces where semantic relationships are captured by geometric relationships

When an AI system processes the concept cloud, it doesn't work with binary membership function; it represents cloudiness as continuous property with features like density, water content, altitude, and shape as continuous values
Neural network image classification produces confidence scores across multiple categories, reflecting the continuous nature of underlying properties rather than forcing binary categorization
If we posit a third truth value like half-true, we are effectively claiming that properties half-exist—but half-existence is metaphysically incoherent; something either exists or it doesn't
Once we admit a third truth value, what principled reason do we have to stop there? This leads to infinite regress undermining the explanatory value of truth values altogether

The AI architecture perspective suggests replacing categorical nouns with degree-adjectives: when an AI categorizes something as cloud, it's actually measuring multiple continuous properties and making practical decisions based on those measurements
Pragmatism's claim that truth is usefulness fails because usefulness varies by person and time while truth-values remain constant

Pragmatism's claim that people should search for usefulness rather than truth fails because usefulness often cannot be determined in advance—valuable discoveries frequently emerge from pursuing seemingly useless knowledge
Usefulness serves as a leading indicator of truth; when data is incomplete, the utility of a model suggests its likely truth
Pragmatism should be reformulated not as an identity claim between truth and usefulness, but as a thesis about the relationship between practical utility and knowledge acquisition

Traditional epistemology presents the subject as passive receptor, reality as something merely to be pictured, and interference effects as incidental—this fails to capture the essentially interactive nature of knowledge
People learn what they have practical incentives to learn; knowledge seeks successful interaction with reality
Knowledge starts as literally perspectival; even objective knowledge depends on interaction-based data driven by practical interests
Passive observation constitutes Level 1; interaction-based observation constitutes Level 2; tool-creating interaction constitutes Level 3; AI development/use constitutes Level 4
Level 2 knowledge requires actual interaction, not just observation; Level 3 knowledge requires creating tools, not just using them; Level 4 knowledge requires engaging with rationality itself
Traditional computers execute predetermined operations quickly and cannot make novel inferences; they are tools of rationality but not rational agents
AI uses non-deterministic, self-correcting protocols, generates unpredictable inferences, represents externalized but autonomous rationality, and can make inferences we might not or cannot make
AI-based interactions generate truly novel empirical observations, create otherwise unobtainable knowledge, and build on but transcend other epistemic faculties
AI represents rational interaction with our capacity for rational interaction and generates unique knowledge through this process—Level 4 interaction
AI development validates pragmatism's core insight about the interactive nature of knowledge while AI itself exemplifies this principle at the highest level of abstraction
Pragmatism was not just a theory of knowledge but a prescient description of knowledge's technological evolution
AI provides concrete, examinable implementations of cognitive processes that allow us to test competing theories about the nature of reasoning, knowledge, and intelligence
The parallel between language and music strengthens both theories: similar architectural constraints might underlie both domains
This synthesis suggests a broader principle: apparently rule-governed behaviors might emerge from appropriately structured neural networks rather than explicit rules

The reconciliation of Chomsky and connectionism points toward a new understanding of mind—one that recognizes both the reality of universal constraints and the fundamentally pattern-based nature of neural processing
Examining discovery processes can teach us about legitimate inference; by studying how AI systems generate successful hypotheses, we learn about valid patterns of reasoning from evidence to theory
The way AI systems learn to distinguish reliable from unreliable patterns supports the view that knowledge requires justification serving as a proper conduit between reality and belief

When AI produces correct outputs through unreliable patterns analogous to Gettier cases, these patterns tend to be revised, mirroring the analysis that knowledge requires justification serving as reliable conduit to reality
The architecture of AI systems aligns naturally with coherentism—knowledge emerges from interconnected networks of mutual support rather than foundational structures
Justi­fication is inherently holistic; in AI systems knowledge emerges from patterns of activation across interconnected nodes with each node's contribution depending on connections to others
AI systems face analogous challenges to humans in developing reliable knowledge representations, suggesting fundamental similarities in the epistemological problems faced by any intelligent system

The success of neural network-based AI combined with observations about human cognition suggests the computational theory of mind is fundamentally inadequate as a framework for understanding intelligence
We need theories that account for the primarily analog nature of cognitive processing while explaining how digital representations emerge from and are grounded in these analog processes
Connectionist approaches emphasizing pattern recognition and continuous processing over discrete symbol manipulation appear better suited to understanding intelligence than computational approaches
Economics studies the generation and allocation of commercial resources
A commercial resource is anything that a person can use or own
An economy exists wherever people exchange the fruits of their labor in a stable arrangement
There is no economy where there is no trade
There is an economy wherever there is trade
An economy is any plurality of people who provide goods and services for one another
Sometimes currency is involved in economies; sometimes it is not
Currency is money; money is a certificate of wealth that is not itself of any value
Dollar bills have no value in and of themselves; their value is purely conventional in nature
Wherever people exchange goods and services, there is an economy; all other factors are irrelevant
If you try to do everything yourself, you will work very hard and your standard of living will be very low
In order to live well, labor must be efficient, meaning a small amount of work must yield a large amount of value
Value is anything that is desired; the term has no moral connotations
In order for a small amount of work to yield a large amount of value, there must be division of labor
Different people must do different things and then exchange the fruits of their labor
The greater the division of labor, the more efficient the economy
An economy of one is not a very efficient economy
A world of total do-it-yourselfers is a world of people who work hard, live badly, and die young
When people work together, their work tends to be relatively efficient and they can live relatively well
Economics is only interested in economies that involve cooperation between different people
There are many different kinds of cooperative arrangements, and they differ dramatically in how well they work
Economics tries to answer which cooperative arrangements work well and which ones don't
Economics is the discipline that identifies the circumstances under which resources are generated and allocated with maximal efficiency
Economics is concerned with politics only to the extent that political arrangements impact economic efficiency
Economics often supplies otherwise empty propositions of ethics and politics with operational definitions that give empirical content to those propositions
Goods and services can be exchanged in one of two ways: directly and indirectly
If I give you money in exchange for a car and you use that money to buy a boat, the exchange was indirect since it involved the intermediary of money
Money is anything that has little or no intrinsic value but that serves as a medium of exchange
Historically, many things have functioned as currency: bags of salt, pebbles, twigs, hunks of gold, and gold coins
Things function as money only if their exchange-value exceeds their intrinsic value
The intrinsic value of a $100 bill is nil, but its exchange-value is high
Direct exchanges are known as barter
Bartering is fine in many contexts but has some limitations
In barter, it is unlikely that what one party has will exactly equal in value what the other party offers
Barter requires an improbable double coincidence of wants and needs between the parties involved
What a given person has and needs is unlikely to align, either qualitatively or quantitatively, with what another given person needs and has
In order for an economy to be efficient, it must have large surpluses
If each person only has just enough to take care of basic needs, people wouldn't be able to trade since they couldn't part with anything without dying
An economy where margins are so thin that people have nothing to give is really only an economy in name only
Where margins are so thin that people have nothing to give, there is no trade and no real economy
Trade is possible when there are surpluses; moreover, trade is possible to the extent that there are surpluses
There are no economies without trade, and there is no trade without surpluses, since one only trades what one has a surplus of
An economy of scale is simply a large economy
There are different ways that an economy can be large
An economy consisting of large numbers of people each with tiny surpluses would technically be large but not what economists mean by economy of scale
Even those who are barely getting by often have surpluses of one kind or another, such as knowledge or talents
People who are not locked into just one job can try their hand at different trades
Being allowed to switch jobs and start businesses creates a fluid and dynamic labor market
When people with surpluses of one kind suffer shortages of another, others who can address those shortages get to work
Economic activity leads to more surpluses—and more shortages—in a continuing cycle
Shortages are addressed when people learn the relevant trades and ply them
An economy in which people are not allowed to change the nature of their work is unlikely to do a good job of addressing shortages
Economies of scale tend to result from efficiency, and efficiency tends to require a willingness to deal with problems in new ways
Efficiency involves adaptation
Writing was invented to keep records of supplies
Farmers who had extra grain used hash-marks to represent bushels of grain
Records enabled farmers to know what they needed to grow next season and what they did not need to grow
Record keeping increased efficiency, leading to more surpluses
Different methods of record keeping converged into systems intelligible to large numbers of people
Common systems of writing were used to record transactions
Writing developed two uses: recording supplies and recording sales
Once sales-transactions were recorded, writing could be used to write promissory notes
Good records help people use their time and energy more efficiently
Ignorance is inefficient, and records minimize ignorance
Written records make it easier for people to loan assets to others
If there are no written records of loans, debtors are likely to lie about what they owe and people will therefore be unlikely to make loans
People who needed capital but did not have anything to exchange for it could get loans once written records existed
People seek loans when they know of economic opportunities that they wish to capitalize on
Loans led to improvements in efficiency since people could capitalize on opportunities even without present assets
Loans can stimulate economic development when they are made to people whose activities generate value
Without loans, people with viable business ideas would have to spend more time accumulating start-up capital and less time creating their businesses
Capital is any asset that is used to generate anything of economic value
Capital refers to assets that are intended to serve an economic purpose
Because writing is of its very nature abstract, it could not exist without bringing mathematics into existence
A single hash-mark represented one bushel; this abstraction led to recognizing that one of anything plus one of that same thing equals two of that thing
Mathematical thought concerns operations that tend to have no observable counterparts and therefore involves the ability to use non-iconic symbols
The existence of writing has had a positive effect on mathematical thought because of the abstract nature of written symbols
When people make loans, they do so for a price known as interest
If I loan you $10 now, I do so only because I believe that in the future you will pay me back more than $10; that extra amount is the interest
Interest can be paid in kind, not just in currency
Investment is when assets are loaned to people who are expected to generate wealth and who for that reason are expected to return those loans plus interest
Investment involves giving people access to capital for which they are not at present able to pay
Finance studies the circumstances under which enterprises are worth investing in and how to raise the funds needed to make necessary investments
Finance answers two questions: When should loans be made? And how can one get the money needed to make those loans?
Economics answers the question: What kinds of social systems are most likely to make it possible for there to be anything worth investing in in the first place?
Financiers don't get to work until there is extra capital to throw around; if that capital doesn't exist, there are no financiers
What a financier does not do is ask how society would have to be different in order to create investment opportunities
As a financier, one only cares about what is, not what could be
The economist's job is to figure out how to tinker with society to create opportunities
A financier picks enterprises believed to be worth investing in and then loans them the money they need to operate
Economics studies the creation and distribution of wealth; finance studies how to identify and capitalize investment-grade businesses
A rigid and inflexible labor market is not likely to be as efficient as a flexible and adaptive labor market
Rigid economies don't work
The existence of written records tends to make labor more efficient
Efficiency requires knowledge, which tends to require records
In an efficient economy, surpluses are created and then used to eliminate shortages
An efficient economy creates more than it needs but promptly reinvests excesses instead of letting them sit idle
Rigid labor markets are the kiss of macroeconomic death
Sometimes rigid labor markets are a consequence of too much government, and sometimes they are consequence of too little government
The relevant question is how much freedom is there, not how much freedom from government is there
Investment is not identical with gambling
There cannot be inflation in a barter-economy, but inflation is generally a small price to pay for the benefits of currency
A high degree of division of labor correlates with economic efficiency and a low degree with economic inefficiency
More division of labor equals more efficiency equals more scale

topic: Two Meanings of Law of Logic
conclusion: The expression 'law of logic' has two meanings: any statement that belongs to a system of logic, and any statement that describes a condition that must be satisfied by any such system
A logic—equivalently, a system of logic—is a recursively defined statement-set
A statement-set is a set whose elements are statements
The English language is a statement-set
A recursively defined set is the smallest set containing some object alpha and also containing phi of x whenever it contains x, where phi is some function defined for each of its own outputs
The class of natural numbers is a recursively defined set—the smallest class containing 0 and containing n+1 whenever it contains n
F(x)=x+1 is a recursive function
A recursive function is one that is defined for each of its own outputs
A recursive statement-function is a recursive function that assigns statements to statements
The negation-function—the function that assigns the negation of a statement to that statement—is a recursive statement-function
In order for a logic to have any value, it must be consistent
A consistent logic is one in which no two of its statements are incompatible with each other
If phi is the recursion that generates a given logic, phi is truth-preservative
A function is truth-preservative if, when p is a true statement, phi of p is also a true statement
Given that phi of p is true whenever p is true, it follows that phi of p is a consequence of p
Q is a consequence of p if there exists a truth-preservative recursion phi such that phi of p equals q
If p is true, and q follows from p, then q is true
The Law of Detachment, better known as modus ponens: if p, and if p then q, then q
The term 'modus ponens' is ambiguous: it has one meaning that is not logic-specific and one meaning specific to any given system of logic
Modus ponens has a logic-non-specific meaning that holds of systems of logic in general and isn't specific to any one system
Given any specific system of logic, modus ponens has a meaning that is specific to that logic
If phi is a truth-preservative recursion and psi is a different truth-preservative recursion, then phi of p is a consequence of p, and psi of p is also a consequence of p
If S is false, then not-S generates a logic
The relation that p bears to phi of p may otherwise be very different from the relation that psi of p bears to p, even though both are consequence relations
The function that, when given statement S, generates 'it is possible that S' is a truth-preservative recursion
The function that, when given S, generates 'it is false that it is false that S' is a truth-preservative recursion
The consequence-relation wears many hats; different truth-preservative recursions are different specifications of it
Modus ponens can be taken to say that if chi is any chosen specification of the consequence relation, then chi of p is true whenever p is true
If L is some specific logic, there is an L-specific version of modus ponens
If zeta is the recursion that generates some specific statement-set L, then the L-specific version of modus ponens says that zeta of s is true whenever s is true
According to the principle of transitivity, if p entails q and q entails r, then p entails r
The principle of transitivity has a general meaning—one that is true of all systems of logic and isn't specific to any one system
The logic-non-specific interpretation of transitivity is that, given any truth-preservative recursion phi, phi of phi of p is true when p is true
If L is some specific system of logic and psi is the recursion that generates L, the L-specific version of transitivity is that psi of psi of p is true if p is true
The L-specific version of transitivity doesn't talk about all truth-preservative recursions; it only concerns the recursion that generates L
Modus tollens is the principle that if p entails q and q is false, then p is false
Everything said about modus ponens and transitivity applies mutatis mutandis to modus tollens
The justifications, and therefore the very meanings, of laws like double negation, excluded middle, and non-contradiction are to be understood in terms of truth-preservative recursions
There is no other way to understand the laws of logic than in terms of truth-preservative recursions
The law of excluded middle states: either p or not p
If you deny the law of excluded middle, it follows that p may be neither true nor false
A logic consists of a set of statements that are assumed to be true, along with the consequences of those statements
If a statement s belongs to a logic, that is either because s is an axiom and therefore true by hypothesis, or because some statement t belongs to that logic and phi of t = s
A statement in a logic is either assumed to be true or it is a consequence of a statement that is assumed to be true
Not-s is either the negation of a statement assumed to be true, in which case it is false, or the negation of a consequence of such a statement, in which case it is false
There is no way that not-s can fail to be false within a logic if s belongs to that logic
Given any system of logic L, a statement s is true by L's lights if s belongs to L
A statement s is false by L's lights if s is the negation of a statement that belongs to L
A logic cannot recognize any statement that doesn't fall into either the true or false category
The L-specific version of the Law of Excluded Middle is that L cannot recognize any statement that is neither true nor false by L's lights
As far as any given system of logic is concerned, any given statement is either true or false
The Law of Non-contradiction is the principle that no statement is both true and false
Suppose some system of logic L contains both s and not-s; in that case, L contains the negation of any given statement that it contains
A logic containing both s and not-s yields no unequivocal verdict as to the truth or falsity of any given statement and is therefore worthless
Given some particular system of logic L, the L-specific version of Non-Contradiction is: if p belongs to L, then not-p does not belong to L
The L-non-specific version of Non-Contradiction is that no system of logic contains the negation of any given statement that it contains
Even if there does exist some statement that is neither true nor false, or both true and false, that statement has no place in any logic

topic: No Place in Logic Means Nonexistence
conclusion: The fact that a statement has no place in any logic means that it has no place anywhere—there exists no such statement
A logic is simply a way of organizing statements in such a way that their deductive interrelations are made clear
There is no logic that contains every true statement
True statements about a given logic do not themselves, as a rule, belong to that logic
Even though no logic contains every true statement, any given true statement belongs to many a logic
Any true statement itself generates a logic
If S is true, then, given some truth-preservative recursion phi, the posterity of S under phi is a logic
It's only if S is neither true nor false that neither S nor its negation generates a logic
Supposing that neither S nor its negation belongs to any logic, it is not necessary to affirm S and it is not necessary to deny S when stating how statements bear on one another
A statement that is neither affirmed nor denied in any logic is as good as non-existent
A statement that is neither true nor false is one whose consequences are neither true nor false
A statement that is neither true nor false is one whose negation is neither true nor false
A statement that is neither true nor false is one where the consequences of whose negation are neither true nor false
A statement that is neither true nor false is a perfect nullity
Logicians and philosophers who fiddle about with multi-valued logics are fiddling

topic: First Sense of Law of Logic
conclusion: The law of logic in the first sense is any statement that belongs to a system of logic

topic: Second Sense of Law of Logic
conclusion: The law of logic in the second sense is any statement that describes a condition that must be satisfied by any system of logic
A system of logic must satisfy certain conditions to be valuable, primarily consistency
Truth-preservation is the key property that makes a recursion logic-generating
The consequence relation is formally captured by the existence of truth-preservative recursions
Different logics may have different recursions generating them, yielding different specific versions of logical laws
The general versions of logical laws apply across all systems of logic
Axioms are true by hypothesis within a logic
Everything in a logic is either an axiom or derivable from axioms via truth-preservative recursion
A logic that contains a contradiction is worthless because it cannot distinguish true from false
The law of excluded middle follows from the structure of logic itself
The law of non-contradiction follows from the requirement that logic be useful
Statements outside any logic are effectively nonexistent
The posterity of a true statement under a truth-preservative recursion constitutes a logic
Metalogical truths about L do not belong to L as a rule
Any statement that fails to generate a logic or whose negation fails to generate a logic is neither true nor false
Neither-true-nor-false statements contribute nothing to deductive organization
Multi-valued logics are idle philosophical exercises
The recursive structure of logic ensures that consequences preserve truth
Possibility operator is one instance of a truth-preservative recursion
Double negation elimination is another instance of a truth-preservative recursion
The smallest set satisfying recursive closure conditions defines the logic generated by given axioms
Logic has both a general theory applicable to all systems and specific instantiations in particular systems
The meaning of logical laws must be understood through recursion theory
A statement belongs to a logic iff it is reachable from axioms via truth-preservative recursion
False statements generate logics via their negations
The organization of deductive interrelations is the essential function of logic
No single logic captures all truths due to metalogical externality
True statements are multiply realizable across different logics
People at the bottom of a hierarchy are far less likely to spurn that hierarchy than to use it against people trying to climb the ranks
Losers want others to share their coffin, even if that involves hyper-valuing the institutions that put them there
The more useless an employee is to the organization, the more unstintingly she will toe that organization's line
People don't give good reviews to writers who don't already have positive reviews—a vicious circle that independent writers cannot break
Communications technology connects us logically while disconnecting us emotionally
Information can be described without being disclosed, which is how information is bought despite Arrow's paradox
In the US, money poured into education is not to improve education but to provide incompetent people with fake employment as administrators
Rationality, unlike intelligence, is inherently reflective and can decide that making a decision is good even when no particular decision is optimal
There is no recursive definition of the class of recursive definitions
There is no formal characterization of formal truth
'True of itself' when meaningful abbreviates some non-reflexive construction; when it doesn't, the term contains an undefined pronoun
When Smith says 'I am lying,' what he is really saying is simply false, not paradoxically self-refuting
Berry's Paradox is resolved by distinguishing canonical from non-canonical ways of naming numbers
Wittgenstein's rule-following paradox collapses into the trivial point that erroneous hypotheses may be compatible with artificially restricted data sets
Quine's indeterminacy of translation is false and only appears true if one considers artificially constricted data-sets
Both Wittgenstein's and Quine's theses are motivated by and presuppose behaviorist psychological theories, showing how broken such theories are
Sorites paradoxes are solved by replacing binary characterizations with comparatives plus contextually supplied benchmarks
n+1 grains of sand are more heapy than n grains; whether something counts as a heap depends on heapiness relative to some benchmark
To be at rest is to fail to move during a non-null interval, so an arrow at any instant is not at rest
If there is an irresistible force, there are no unmovable objects, and vice versa
The more stringent the licensing process for therapists, the less effective therapists are
For every hour of psychiatric treatment received, one needs two hours to undo the damage
The more money spent on economic research, the more useless the results
Lawyers are better at defending the guilty than at defending the innocent
Unions are needed to help people keep jobs only because they prevent people from getting jobs in the first place
People with modest responsibilities often intentionally fail to fulfill them to inflate their own importance
Professors often withhold the little information they have to make it seem more valuable
Any finite number can be represented as the sum of an infinite series, so traversing infinitely many distances in finite time is not paradoxical
Space-time regions do not have places since they are constituents, not occupants, of space-time
High probabilities are not interchangeable with certainties in all contexts; acceptance is not belief
Beliefs are not justified on strictly statistical grounds but by being more explanatory than their negation
People who try to avoid working end up working harder than people who don't try to avoid it
Slackers play a defensive game and are forced to take whatever opportunities come their way, constantly short-selling themselves
Extremely successful people work mainly at choosing what kind of work to do and spend relatively little energy doing work-proper
The more efficient an economy is, the more people tend to be prevented from profiting from it
As economies become more efficient, people become more economically useless and therefore more dependent on welfare
Only principled generalizations can be confirmed; 'All ravens are black' read as principled is not equivalent to 'All non-black things are non-ravens'
When read as a principled generalization, 'all x's are y's' has nomic or causal content and is not equivalent to its contrapositive
Knowledge of the future is based on continuities, not regularities; for x to cause y is for y to be a continuation of x
Regularities tell us where to look for continuities, but until we have knowledge of continuity, we don't have good reason to believe in the causal connection
The legitimacy of inference from cause to effect lies in the irrationality of positing spontaneities
Enumerative induction is either non-existent or illegitimate; legitimate inferences about the future are based on knowledge of continuities
We may know that x caused y without knowing any other cases of x-like events followed by y-like events, if we see the continuity
The new riddle of induction is a non-riddle since it isn't on the basis of concomitances but of continuities that we know what will happen
Names are mere labels that 'pick up' descriptive information in the course of being learned
Semantics isn't known in a vacuum; how a person knows literal meaning affects what sentences mean to him
A belief must be justified to be knowledge, but it isn't necessary that one know that justification
Knowledge starts with beliefs that are not knowledge; useful beliefs are retained because they are useful, not because their owner knows them to be
Seeking knowledge involves knowing of a description that it is instantiated but not knowing what that instance is
The ability to learn presupposes knowledge of a kind, but such knowledge is constitutive of one's mind and therefore not acquired
